text: your brain knows within point oh two
seconds if your body is under attack
from a chili pepper but not because of
your taste buds the hot spice in a
pepper isn't a taste at all it is pure
pain heat sensing pain receptors in your
mouths and a signal to your brain that
your tongue is literally on fire it's
the same response as if you touch the
hot stove so how does a super hot pepper
make you feel the burn this is a
habanero pepper and this is Jacob would
you like a pepper yeah loved one see
Jacob is an insane person and he eats
spicy foods for fun the crazy thing is
that you know the main ingredient in the
habanero which is 35 times spicier than
a jalapeno pepper by the way it's HAP's
Aysen and capsaicin is also the active
ingredient in pepper spray why don't you
go ahead and take a bite of that Jacob
down the hatch oh it's kicking in now
Wow he's twitching a little bit there it
only takes seven seconds for the pepper
they've reached Jacob's stomach so what
exactly is going on in his body right
now
Jakob's 10,000 tastebuds are on fire
a split-second after hitting his tongue
the habaneros heat triggers the exact
same sensory neurons that are affected
by abrasive injury to the body causing
the same burning sensation as road rash
his nervous system has been tricked into
thinking he's hot and a moment later his
3.8 million pores spring open making him
sweat this former perspiration is called
gustatory sweating and it's concentrated
around his face hairline and neck it
cools him down by evaporating and
thereby removing the heat from his skin
down in his stomach the capsaicin is
waging war not on him but on bacteria
killing 75% of the harmful strains that
infect food this is why people in warmer
climates eat spicier foods it actually
cools them off and it kills the bacteria
that thrive in hotter wetter
environments you know Jacob I think it
might be time to put you out of your
misery are you interested in maybe some
water some milk yeah YUM
capsaicin is concentrated in oils in the
peppers water and oil don't mix so water
is useless for extinguishing the heat
alcohol can dissolve capsaicin but beer
isn't concentrated enough to be
effective the best bet is milk it
contains a protein called casein that
surrounds the capsaicin and washes it
away like soap what a wimp
